snippet.textDisplay: Avatar The Way of Water was absolutely phenomenal, 13 years after the first movie, James Cameron perfectly recaptured the magic and what made the first Avatar so special, so much added world building, the amazing visuals, action, the stunning cinematography, the use of water as the theme for the movie was an excellent idea. Loved how the movie allowed us to explore different tribes and regions of Pandora, the world of Avatar has so much depth. Just an amazing overall movie. 👏👏👏
snippet.textOriginal: Avatar The Way of Water was absolutely phenomenal, 13 years after the first movie, James Cameron perfectly recaptured the magic and what made the first Avatar so special, so much added world building, the amazing visuals, action, the stunning cinematography, the use of water as the theme for the movie was an excellent idea. Loved how the movie allowed us to explore different tribes and regions of Pandora, the world of Avatar has so much depth. Just an amazing overall movie. 👏👏👏

snippet.textDisplay: I don't disagree with most of your points, except that you seem to ignore that these are two of the most popular films ever. Cameron wants to have a political influence on his audience and can you be sure that these films would be more effective for the world's biggest audience if that were more dramatically complex? Yes they are propaganda, as are many films, but propaganda for a good cause is fine with me, as much as a political advertisement would be. Also I challenge your assumption that the Navi represent 'our ancestors'. There are people living today in cultures today that resemble the Navi way of life, but more than that could it not be that they are to represent a utopian way of life? Right there is a strawman fallacy of your own. You and I would prefer these films more if they were more dramatically sophisticated but would they then be actually better at fulfilling their intended purpose?
snippet.textOriginal: I don't disagree with most of your points, except that you seem to ignore that these are two of the most popular films ever. Cameron wants to have a political influence on his audience and can you be sure that these films would be more effective for the world's biggest audience if that were more dramatically complex? Yes they are propaganda, as are many films, but propaganda for a good cause is fine with me, as much as a political advertisement would be. Also I challenge your assumption that the Navi represent 'our ancestors'. There are people living today in cultures today that resemble the Navi way of life, but more than that could it not be that they are to represent a utopian way of life? Right there is a strawman fallacy of your own. You and I would prefer these films more if they were more dramatically sophisticated but would they then be actually better at fulfilling their intended purpose?

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the simplest way to describe what is bad about the movies, is that everything feels like a caricature of itself. The villain is villainy cus they're a villain. The good guy is good because they're the good guy. The dialogie is indeed a dialogue. The plot is very in-your-face, because it has to make sure you understand that it is, indeed, a plot. The messaging messages very directly.

There is no subtlety, no nuance. Every aspect sees what it has to communicate, and just brunt force straightlines towards it -whereas had it been naturally flowing, it would dip and bend and navigate its way through in a manner that feels genuine and nuanced, instead of just paving a straight path with sledgehammers and dynamite.

---
This is not to say there aren't great aspects of the movies. This, too, is nuanced. But I will never truly appreciate them in full, because not all of their entirety is appreciation worthy.

The Avatar movies make me feel like I would enjoy them more if I was less intelligent.
snippet.textOriginal:
I think the simplest way to describe what is bad about the movies, is that everything feels like a caricature of itself. The villain is villainy cus they're a villain. The good guy is good because they're the good guy. The dialogie is indeed a dialogue. The plot is very in-your-face, because it has to make sure you understand that it is, indeed, a plot. The messaging messages very directly.

There is no subtlety, no nuance. Every aspect sees what it has to communicate, and just brunt force straightlines towards it -whereas had it been naturally flowing, it would dip and bend and navigate its way through in a manner that feels genuine and nuanced, instead of just paving a straight path with sledgehammers and dynamite.

---
This is not to say there aren't great aspects of the movies. This, too, is nuanced. But I will never truly appreciate them in full, because not all of their entirety is appreciation worthy.

The Avatar movies make me feel like I would enjoy them more if I was less intelligent.

snippet.textDisplay: Ironically, by making the Navi strong warriors who killed anyone who set foot on their planet because of religion, the movie ends up making the humans actions far more justifiable. Because, by refusing to negotiate with humans, and by sticking to religious zealotry and xenophobia, the Navi force the RDA to turn to violence.
snippet.textOriginal: Ironically, by making the Navi strong warriors who killed anyone who set foot on their planet because of religion, the movie ends up making the humans actions far more justifiable. snippet.textDisplay: As a visual fx artist myself, this doesn't justify how much work that we put into when working on CGI like this. And I came from the most modern iteration of VFX where everything is exponentially easier... it's still extremely hard. Can't really begin to explain the work without exaggerating. In the VFX breakdown, you see people in motion capture doing performances and then after a few swipes, they became this CGI version of themselves. Nah, the actors are just references. Those dots almost do nothing in editing. Consider the fact that this film was from 2009 where CGI is still progressing in its innovation. The VFX artist use the actors as reference, but they hand animate everything frame by frame from scratch. It means it can take 3 hours just to get their mouth movements or body language right every 16 frames. Subtle movements conveys emotion like breathing in reaction to fear. There are also physics to convey said emotions such as subtle twitching of eyes, the expansion of nose in face of in face of depression, or the subtle movement of ears when lying, even the subtle flex in their skins and muscle during a normal conversation are animated from scratch. There's no bitter way of saying this but CGI animations are (usualkly) much harder than 2D animation (anime, cartoons, etc). In cartoon (or anime), there are certain principles that let them skip some frames that'll still look extremely well in play because anime are played in 24fps, especially they use CGI on their series now-a-days. No worries, I am not saying 2d animators had it easy, it's the complete opposite. Animators (handrawn and VFX artists alike) should be appreciated more. My big bro worked for the second Avatar Film. I am a visual fx artist but I do not have that kind of experience like my brother does.
snippet.textOriginal: As a visual fx artist myself, this doesn't justify how much work that we put into when working on CGI like this. And I came from the most modern iteration of VFX where everything is exponentially easier... it's still extremely hard. Can't really begin to explain the work without exaggerating. In the VFX breakdown, you see people in motion capture doing performances and then after a few swipes, they became this CGI version of themselves. Nah, the actors are just references. Those dots almost do nothing in editing. Consider the fact that this film was from 2009 where CGI is still progressing in its innovation. The VFX artist use the actors as reference, but they hand animate everything frame by frame from scratch. It means it can take 3 hours just to get their mouth movements or body language right every 16 frames. Subtle movements conveys emotion like breathing in reaction to fear. There are also physics to convey said emotions such as subtle twitching of eyes, the expansion of nose in face of in face of depression, or the subtle movement of ears when lying, even the subtle flex in their skins and muscle during a normal conversation are animated from scratch. There's no bitter way of saying this but CGI animations are (usualkly) much harder than 2D animation (anime, cartoons, etc). In cartoon (or anime), there are certain principles that let them skip some frames that'll still look extremely well in play because anime are played in 24fps, especially they use CGI on their series now-a-days. No worries, I am not saying 2d animators had it easy, it's the complete opposite. Animators (handrawn and VFX artists alike) should be appreciated more. My big bro worked for the second Avatar Film. I am a visual fx artist but I do not have that kind of experience like my brother does.
